ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Univariate, bivariate, and multivariate statistical analysis methods applicable to archaeology as well as how to use statistical packages JMP and PAST.
An introduction to statistics and how to use it in archeological analysis
I learned how to properly use statistics to analyze archaeological data

A helpful overview of statistical methods in archaeology  including the math, but also the implications for archaeological theory (e.g. "can we ever really 'sample' a site?", etc).  For students who are newer to archaeology, the course also offers good practice at effectively reading/interpreting archaeological science journals. It is split about 50-50 between univariate/bivariate methods on the one hand, and multivariate methods on the other.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We covered a lot of analytical methods with a clear progression through the term. Assessments and their feedback were clear and useful. A very good skills-building course overall.
I appreciated the use of real-world examples. The pacing of the second half of the course could have been a little slower

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you intend to seriously pursue archaeology in the future. It is not an easy QR credit, so look elsewhere if that's what you're here for.
If you are an anthropology major, it would be best to take this course
I would strongly recommend this course to another student.
Yes, I would recommend this course to all archaeology students.

This course covers enough ground in terms of common archaeological methods, archaeological theory, etc. that it would definitely appeal to anyone interested in archaeology. That said, it is probably most useful for undergraduate archaeology majors who have not already taken any particularly advanced statistics/mathematics courses.
